g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Mediator Define an object that encapsulates how a set of obje...
g.text: MediatorDefine an object that encapsulates how a set of objects interact, to ensure varying their interaction independently.

g.title: Rectangle.119
g.desc: The interaction context between objects should be modifiable ...
g.text: The interaction context between objects should be modifiable without a lot of sub-classing or change

g.title: Folded Corner.205
g.desc: The Mediator pattern compliments the Single Responsibility by...

g.text: The Mediator pattern compliments the Single Responsibility by separating the interaction between objects from their core logic. The Mediator, which facilitates this interaction context, has positive impact on the maintainability of the code. In specific, the understandability and changeability of the code. All aspects are compared against an implementation where interactors(=Colleagues) reference each other directly. Understandability, because the Mediator replaces many-to-many interactions with one-to-many interactions. The interactions of the Colleagues are centralized into a single place instead of scattered across the code base. This makes comprehending the interaction between objects easier. Changeability, because ‘swapping’ or adding a new interaction context becomes easier. This is because the interaction context of the Colleagues is centralized. The Mediator can be replaced by another Mediator via single inheritance. In contrast, having the interaction logic scattered across the code base will result in ‘multi-sub-classing’.

g.title: Rectangle.210
g.desc: Centralize the interaction context of objects to simplify und...
g.text: Centralize the interaction context of objects to simplify understanding

g.title: Folded Corner.216
g.desc: The Mediator pattern centralizes multi-point, ‘complex’ objec...

g.text: The Mediator pattern centralizes multi-point, ‘complex’ object interaction into a single point. This simplifies understanding the interaction context between objects. This is because the logic is in one place. In contrast, having the interaction logic scattered around the Colleagues will have negative impact on the maintainability, because it will be harder to comprehend the ‘whole’. Examples of the Mediator pattern are the controller in MVC (Model-View-Controller) or the View Model in MVVM (Model-View-View Model).

g.title: Folded Corner.196
g.desc: The Mediator pattern could violate the Single Responsibility ...

g.text: The Mediator pattern could violate the Single Responsibility Principle, because it tends to become a ‘god’ object or monolith. This has negative impact on the testability, stability and understandability of the Mediator. Testability, because the Mediator contains the interaction logic of a vast variety of Colleagues. This means the Mediator has a complex dependency model, that makes it hard to test. Dependencies degrade mock-ability and isolated testing. Stability, because changes in the interaction of Colleague ‘A’ and ‘B’ might unintentionally reflect on interaction ‘C’ and ‘D’. This is because the interaction context is in one place. In relation, the Mediator might introduce a Single Point of Failure. This might be an undesired side affect, e.g.: if interaction ‘A’ and ‘B’ fails all interactions fail. Understandability, because the complexity in the Mediator grows with the amount of colleague interactions. This has negative impact on maintainability of the code.

g.title: Folded Corner.235
g.desc: The Mediator is responsible for controlling and coordinating ...

g.text: The Mediator is responsible for controlling and coordinating the interactions of a group of objects. The Mediator defines the interaction context of the individual parts of a system. Those parts are called Colleagues. Colleagues can interact with each other directly, but this makes changing or extending the context, in which those Colleagues interact, more complicated. The complexity arises, because the interaction context is scattered around these Colleagues. This will require extension via inheritance or change in multiple places of our system. This becomes even more complicated when there are an ‘extensive’ amount of Colleagues interacting. A context change could mean that the amount of sub-classes or changes grows ‘fast’. This makes the overall system less stable and/or more complex. The Mediator pattern extracts this scattered context in to a centralized place. Colleagues are only dependent on a Mediator. A switch in the interaction context would mean sub classing only the Mediator. This reduces the overall complexity of the system by minimizing the amount of required sub classes.

g.title: Rectangle.238
g.desc: Object reusability is difficult because it contains a lot of ...
g.text: Object reusability is difficult because it contains a lot of dependencies

g.title: Folded Corner.251
g.desc: The Mediator pattern prevents Colleagues from explicitly refe...

g.text: The Mediator pattern prevents Colleagues from explicitly referring to each other. This results in Colleagues becoming more reusable in a different interaction context. In the most simplistic sense this is true. However, the interaction logic (between Colleagues) is shifted to the respective Mediator. This means the coupling is still there and reusability does not fully apply. The interaction logic is just ‘moved’ to a different place! Mediator logic is often not reusable and requires redefinition in other Mediators. This might result in code duplication. To use the Mediator pattern to overcome code duplication (= gain reusability) seems a bit off. This can of course not be stated with 100% certainty, because it dependents on the specific implementation details. If two Mediators almost don’t have anything in common or if the respective Colleague provides a lot of other logic (besides interaction logic), than there might be an ‘overall’ reusability gain. To use the Mediator pattern for reusability seems not to be the strongest argument. The main advantage of the pattern is to improve maintainability of complex interaction logic. This maintainability gain is assured by centralizing the interaction logic, that simplifies changing and understanding.

g.title: Folded Corner.258
g.desc: The Mediator pattern compliments the Open Closed Principle by...

g.text: The Mediator pattern compliments the Open Closed Principle by enabling introduction of a new interaction context (=Mediator) without changing the respective Colleagues or existing Mediators. This enhances the stability of the code. All aspects are compared against an implementation where interactors(=Colleagues) reference each other directly. Stability, because existing product and test code do not require change when interaction context between interactors(=Colleagues) changes. The Colleagues don’t interact directly but via a Mediator, which allows interconnecting different Colleagues without changing existing ones. In contrast, a Colleague being directly dependent on another concrete Colleague or interface would require change when interconnecting with a complete different Colleague type or interface. The Mediator facilitates this Colleague interaction and provides a simple, generic interface towards them. The Mediator abstraction allows introduction of a new interaction context without changing existing ones.
